{{Infobox company | name = Ford Otomotiv Sanayi A.Ş. | logo = Ford Otosan logo.svg | logo_size = 250px | type = [[S.A. (corporation)|Anonim Şirket]] | traded_as = {{IMKB|FROTO}} | industry = [[Automotive industry|Automotive]] | foundation = 1959 | location = [[Gölcük, Kocaeli|Gölcük]], [[Turkey]] | key_people = [[Rahmi Koç]] ([[President (corporate title)|President]]) | products = [[Automobile]]s, [[light commercial vehicle]]s, [[truck]]s | production = 373,007 vehicles (2017){{cite web |title=Ford Otosan 2017 Annual Report |url=https://www.fordotosan.com.tr/doc/wHG4NgJr06AyPNiaHPvUC12LlshLdrym9CXbTp7jYf3pPzLHKvnd88TIQ8V5nfoASTCoIp1CS6rVyn_b5DamhAFSF0qhndW4x29rYOTKxoXsigDGz4X8ayeQk79FduFeUPy8iqPOh5Y-K-nfxwzdvg2 |publisher=Ford Otosan |accessdate=4 November 2018 |pages=5 |language=English |date=25 April 2018}} | revenue = {{increase}} [[US$]] 4.67 [[1,000,000,000 (number)|billion]] (2017) | net_income = {{increase}} US$ 270 million (2017) | owner = [[Ford Motor Company]] (41%)
[[Koç Holding]] (41%) | num_employees = {{increase}} 11,501 (2017) | homepage = {{URL|www.fordotosan.com.tr}} }} '''Ford Otomotiv Sanayi A.Ş.''' (''Ford Automotive Industry'') is an [[automotive]] manufacturing company based in [[Turkey]] that is equally owned by [[Ford Motor Company]] and [[Koç Holding]].{{cite web|title=Ford Motor Company and Koç Holding celebrate 50th anniversary of Ford Otosan joint venture|url=http://media.ford.com/article_display.cfm?article_id=32868|publisher=Ford Motor Company|date=28 June 2010}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} It was established in its current form in 1977, with original relations dating back to 1928.{{cite web|title=2009 Annual Report|url=http://www.fordotosan.com.tr/downloads/yatirimciiliskileri/2009_Annual_Report_FO.pdf|publisher=Ford Otosan|date=23 July 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120915065412/http://www.fordotosan.com.tr/downloads/yatirimciiliskileri/2009_Annual_Report_FO.pdf|archivedate=15 September 2012|df=}} It currently operates five facilities throughout the country,{{cite web|title=Facilities|url=http://www.fordotosan.com.tr/en/facilities.htm|publisher=Ford Otosan|accessdate=16 July 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131010042316/http://www.fordotosan.com.tr/en/facilities.htm|archivedate=10 October 2013|df=}} and is headquartered in [[Gölcük, Kocaeli|Gölcük]], with a second location in [[İnönü, Eskişehir|İnönü]].{{cite web|title=Ford Otosan|url=http://www.osd.org.tr/otosan.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130528030228/http://www.osd.org.tr/otosan.htm|archivedate=28 May 2013|publisher=Otomotiv Sanayii Derneği|accessdate=16 July 2013}} ==History== The collaboration began in 1928, when [[Vehbi Koç]] was assigned as Ford dealer in [[Ankara]].{{cite web|title=Ford dünyasının en kalitelisi oldu yeni projeleri almakta zorlanmadı|url=http://otomobil.milliyet.com.tr/ford-dunyasinin-en-kalitelisi-oldu-yeni-projeleri-almakta-zorlanmadi/otonostalji/haberdetay/22.04.2012/1531579/default.htm|publisher=Milliyet|date=22 April 2012}} The following year, the Turkish national assembly granted to Ford the right to install a local assembly operation in a free zone located in Istanbul's port area. Limited numbers of vehicles were assembled there until 1934, when these activities were suspended.Odin, L.C. ''World in Motion 1939 - The whole of the year's automobile production''. Belvedere Publishing, 2015. ASIN: B00ZLN91ZG. In 1959, the foundation of the '''Otosan''' factory was held in [[Istanbul]], and in 1960 the [[Ford Consul]] was the first model to be produced at the plant, followed by the [[Ford Thames 300E|Thames]] and the [[Ford Thames 400E|Thames Trader]] van.{{cite web|title=Tarihçe|url=http://www.fordotosan.com.tr/tarihce.htm|publisher=Ford Otosan|accessdate=16 July 2013}} In 1965, the D1210 truck was added to production, and in 1966, the [[Anadol]], the first mass-production passenger vehicle developed in Turkey. In 1967, the [[Ford Transit]] also began production and in 1973, the Anadol STC-16, the first sports car developed in Turkey. In 1977, the company signed a license agreement with Ford and the company's name was changed to '''Ford Otosan'''. In 1979, took place the groundbreaking ceremony for a new factory in [[İnönü, Eskişehir]], which began production of the [[Ford Cargo]] in 1983. Also that year, Ford increased its share of ownership in the company to 30 percent. In 1985, the [[Ford Taunus TC#Turkey|Ford Taunus]] begins production at the Istanbul plant, and in 1986 the official opening ceremony for the İnönü engine plant is held. In 1992, the newer [[Ford Transit]] was put into production, and in 1993 the [[Ford Escort (Europe)|Ford Escort]] replaced the Ford Taunus on the production lines. In 1997, Ford further increased its share in the company to 41 percent, becoming equal partner with Koç Holding in the joint venture. In 1998, the groundbreaking ceremony was held for the new factory in [[Gölcük, Kocaeli]], that became operational in 2001, replacing the Istanbul facility. It is aimed mainly at commercial vehicle production, and manufactures the [[Ford Transit]] and the [[Ford Transit Connect]], both models being marketed worldwide. In 2003, the company launched a new generation of the Ford Cargo heavy-duty truck.{{cite web|title=Investor Presentation March 2012|url=http://www.fordotosan.com.tr/downloads/yatirimciiliskileri/Investor%20Presentation%20March%202012.pdf|publisher=Ford Otosan|date=26 March 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120905013321/http://www.fordotosan.com.tr/downloads/yatirimciiliskileri/Investor%20Presentation%20March%202012.pdf|archivedate=5 September 2012|df=}} In September 2012, Ford revealed its new version of the [[Ford Transit|Transit]],{{cite web|title=Ford Reveals All-New Global Transit and Transit Connect Commercial Vehicles at ‘Go Further’ Event|url=http://media.ford.com/news/fordrevealsallnewglobaltransitandtransitconnectcommercialvehiclesatgofurtherevent.htm|publisher=Ford Motor Company|date=6 September 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121123082752/http://media.ford.com/news/fordrevealsallnewglobaltransitandtransitconnectcommercialvehiclesatgofurtherevent.htm|archivedate=23 November 2012|df=}} and in January 2013 the new Cargo heavy truck was unveiled.{{cite web|title=Ford’s Turkish designed heavy truck unveiled|url=http://www.invest.gov.tr/en-US/infocenter/news/Pages/280113-ford-turkish-designed-heavy-truck-hits-markets-worldwide.aspx|publisher=Invest in Turkey|date=28 January 2013}} The latter was co-developed by Ford Otosan in partnership with [[Ford Brasil|Ford Brazil]],{{cite web|title=Ford to launch Turkish-developed new heavy truck|url=http://www.invest.gov.tr/en-US/infocenter/news/Pages/060812-ford-turkey-manufacturing-trucks-for-global-markets.aspx|publisher=Invest in Turkey|date=6 August 2012}} and will be manufactured in both countries. In September 2018, at the IAA Commercial Vehicles show in Hannover, Germany, Ford introduced an electric tractor trailer concept vehicle dubbed the F-Vision, which would have Level 4 autonomous driving capability.{{Cite web|url=https://www.autotrader.ca/newsfeatures/20180928/ford-turkey-shows-off-f-vision-concept-electric-semi/|title=Ford Turkey Shows Off F-Vision Concept Electric Semi|last=Williams|first=Evan|date=2018-09-28|website=AutoTrader.ca|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} ==Facilities== The company operates five facilities throughout the country. The Kocaeli Plant, located in [[Gölcük, Kocaeli|Gölcük]], was opened in 2001, and has been the main global production center for the [[Ford Transit|Transit]] and the [[Ford Transit Connect|Transit Connect]].{{cite web|title=2010 Annual Report|url=http://www.fordotosan.com.tr/downloads/yatirimciiliskileri/2010_Faaliyet_Raporu_%C4%B0ng.pdf|publisher=Ford Otosan|date=27 July 2011}} It has an annual production capacity of 320,000 vehicles and has its own port. The [[İnönü, Eskişehir|İnönü]] Plant, located in Eskişehir, began operating in 1982, and has been the production center of the Cargo heavy truck, as well as for engines and powertrains. It has an annual capacity of 10,000 trucks, 66,000 engines and 45,000 gearboxes. The Kartal Parts Distribution Center, located in the [[Sancaktepe]] district of Istanbul, has been operating since 1998, and it is the marketing centre of the company's marketing, sales, after-sales and spare parts operations. The Sancaktepe Engineering Center, located in the [[Sancaktepe]] district of Istanbul, was established in 2014, and is responsible for the development of the newest products and technologies. It employs over 1000 product development engineers. The Yeniköy plant started production of the Transit/Tourneo Courier in the second quarter of 2014. It is located within the Kocaeli facility, but as a different production plant, with a starting capacity of 110,000 vehicles per year.{{cite web|title=Annual Report 2014|url=http://www.fordotosan.com.tr/downloads/yatirimciiliskileri/2014%20FR%20EN.pdf|publisher=Ford Otosan|date=7 May 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702033331/http://www.fordotosan.com.tr/downloads/yatirimciiliskileri/2014%20FR%20EN.pdf|archivedate=2 July 2015|df=}} ==Products== ===Historic=== [[File:Ford_Consul_ca_1962.jpg|thumb|right|Ford Consul Mk II]] [[File:2014_Ford_Tourneo_Courier_(fl).jpg|thumb|right|Ford Transit Courier]] * [[Ford Consul]] (1960–1961) * [[Thames Trader]] (1961–1965) * Ford D1210 (1965–1983) * [[Anadol]] (1966–1984) * [[Anadol]] STC-16 (1973–1975) * [[Ford Taunus]] (1985–1993) * [[Ford Escort (Europe)|Ford Escort]] (1993–1999) * [[Ford Transit Connect]] (2002–2013) ===Current=== * [[Ford Transit]] (1965–present) * [[Ford Cargo]] (1983–present) * [[Ford Transit Custom]] (2012–present) * [[Ford Transit Courier]] (2014–present) * [[Ford F-MAX]] heavy truck (2018–)https://www.freightwaves.com/news/technology/ford-trucks-fmax-iaa-2018https://www.truckinginfo.com/313838/ford-launches-f-max-tractor-for-global-markets == See also == *[[Ford Ecotorq engine]] *[[List of companies of Turkey]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.fordotosan.com.tr/en Official website] {{Koç family}} {{FordEurope}} {{Ford Motor Company assembly plants}} {{Turkish automobile brands and manufacturers}} {{Istanbul Stock Exchange companies}} {{Coord|40|43|24|N|29|51|11|E|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Motor vehicle manufacturers of Turkey]] [[Category:Ford of Europe factories]] [[Category:Companies based in İzmit]] [[Category:Vehicle manufacturing companies established in 1959]] [[Category:1959 establishments in Turkey]] [[Category:Joint ventures]] [[Category:Koç family]] [[Category:Companies listed on the Istanbul Stock Exchange]]

page.title: Friend of the Society of Experimental Test Pilots Award

revision.comment: /* Recipients */ added 2016 and 2017 recipients
revision.text:
The '''Friend of the Society Award''' pays tribute to individuals or organizations who have provided an exceptional and notable contribution to the operation and the objectives of the [[Society of Experimental Test Pilots]] (SETP).<ref name=SETP_Friend_Criteria>{{cite web |title=Friend of the Society Award Criteria |url=http://www.setp.org/criteria/friend-of-the-society.html |date= |work= |publisher=Society of Experimental Test Pilots |accessdate=January 15, 2010}}</ref> The award was established in 1995 and is sponsored by SETP.<ref name=SETP_Friend_Criteria/> A Friend of the Society is not a member of SETP, and there is no requirement for a Friend of the Society to be awarded every year.<ref name=SETP_Friend_Criteria/> Honorees are announced at the annual Awards Banquet in [[Los Angeles, California]] where they receive public recognition and a commemorative plaque.<ref name=SETP_Friend_Criteria/>
== Criteria == A Friend of the Society must meet the following criteria:<ref name=SETP_Friend_Criteria/> #Candidates may not be members of the Society and it is preferred that candidates not be eligible for membership in the Society. #The candidate must, over a significant time period, have made a significant contribution to the operation support and the objectives of the Society.
== Recipients == Recipients of this award, from 1995 to present, include:<ref name=SETP_Friend_Recipients>{{cite web |title=Friend of the Society Award Recipients |url=http://www.setp.org/winners/friend-of-the-society-recipients.html |date= |work= |publisher=Society of Experimental Test Pilots |accessdate=October 10, 2015}}</ref>
*1995—[[Barron Hilton]], [[Hilton Hotels Corporation]] *1996—Dr. Gerry Morton, Robert Staubli *1998—[[David Hartman (TV personality)|David Hartman]], Rodman-Downs Ltd. *1999—Chaplain William Willson, CHCUSN (Ret) *2000—Dr. [[Richard P. Hallion]], [[United States Air Force|USAF]] Historian and Dr. James O. Young, [[Air Force Flight Test Center|AFFTC]] Chief Historian *2001—Bob Lafey, [[Boeing]], Audio Visual and Claude Pasquis, CLP Enterprises, Audio Visual *2002—Dan Sabovich<ref name=Sabovich_Obit>{{cite web |title=Former Airport Manager Dan Sabovich Dies At 79 |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/FORMER+AIRPORT+MANAGER+DAN+SABOVICH+DIES+AT+79-a0128988982 |work=The Free Library |publisher=Farlex |location=Huntingdon Valley, PA |year=2005 |accessdate=June 26, 2016}}</ref> *2003—Fred Johnsen *2004—Trevor Bushell, [[BAE Systems]] and John Hodgeson *2005—Tom Roberts *2006—Michael A. Dornheim and Ken Szalai *2007—Dana Kilanowski<ref name=Kilanowski_Bio>{{cite web |title=Dana Kilanowski Biography |url=http://www.afftcmuseum.org/dana_kilanowski_16.html |date= |work= |publisher=Air Force Flight Test Center Museum |year= |accessdate=September 29, 2012}}</ref> *2009—Hank Caruso, ForeFeathers Enterprises *2010—Michael J. Fahrney, The Boeing Company *2011—Richard R. Schock, FMS Financial Partners *2012—Paula S. Smith, Executive Director, SETP *2013—Katherine Benjamin *2014—Steve Lewis, [[National Test Pilot School]] *2015—Carol Guthrie, Former AFFTC Deputy Comptroller and Author *2016—Dennis Archuleta, [[Northrop Grumman]] and Louise Cullina, [[Air Line Pilots Association, International|Airline Pilots Association]] (ALPA) *2017—Heidi Biermeier
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Aviation awards]]

revision.comment: /* top */reduce overlinking
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=March 2018}}
{{Infobox company | name = Genomics Sector Innovation Network (G-SIN) | logo = [[File:GSI logo.png|Genomics Sector Innovation Network logo]] | type = [[Nonprofit organization]] | foundation = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada | location = [[MaRS Discovery District]] | homepage = [http://www.g-sin.com Genomics Sector Innovation Network (G-SIN)] }}
The '''genomics sector innovation network''' portal was developed to highlight and support the [[genomics]] sector in [[Ontario]] and was created by the [[Ontario Genomics Institute]].
== What is Genomics? ==
[[Genomics]] is the holistic, systematic, and high-throughput characterization of [[genome]]s—the full complement of [[DNA]] underlying the genetic make-up of a given organism. Though smaller genomes had been previously completely sequenced, the consideration of the possibility of doing so for the entire human genome crystallized the notion of a new paradigm for the life sciences, intended to enable and accelerate traditional hypothesis-driven research.
Genomics has since been generalized to capture the application of this approach to any and all aspects of life sciences, but many of these applications have also stimulated the coining of a much broader vocabulary of "[[omics]]" applications.
The growth of genomics and the resulting boom in technology development have created a tremendous global impact on our knowledge and understanding of the molecular basis of life. This impact ranges from drug and pesticide discovery to industrial enzymology, to crop and livestock cultivation, to environmental remediation, to natural resource management, and to criminal and civil law. This impact of these changes in technological underpinnings has also been reflected in other sectors focused more on societal implications, including public policy, education, journalism, fine arts, and entertainment.
== Genomics in Ontario == The genomics sector in Ontario consists of the individuals, institutions, and associations—a sub-set of the province's life-sciences industry—who are working:
* to create deeper understanding in the life sciences through genomics; * to generate and maintain genomics resources (databases, instruments, reagents, software) for use in the public and private sectors; * to translate this understanding and these resources into products which may be beneficial to society through the development of new products and services that can be distributed in the commercial marketplace.
This industry includes universities and private research institutions, individual and institutional investors, biotechnology, pharmaceutical and related companies, and the various public and private institutions devoted to servicing and supporting these enterprises.
There are more than 500 scientists conducting research in genomics located at 20 universities, research institutions, hospitals and government laboratories across the province. These individuals are generating genomics discoveries and innovations as well as using genomic tools and products.
'''Life Sciences Industry'''
* More than half the country's brand-name pharmaceutical and medical devices industries and almost half the medical biotechnology industry are located in Ontario. * Ontario is North America's 3rd largest regional concentration of biotechnology firms and the 6th largest in revenues earned. * The province's bio-medical sector employs more than 33,000 highly educated people and posted more than $1.0 billion in revenues in 2002. * The biotechnology sector is built on world-class science and is involved in leading edge research in molecular biology and medical genetics. * Ontario's pharmaceutical sector employs more than 15,000 talented people and includes global giants like GlaxoSmithKline, Amgen, Biogen, Genzyme, Eli Lilly, Pfizer and home-grown stars like Biovail Corporation, Apotex, and Patheon. * Ontario has achieved worldwide recognition as a site for clinical trials because of its large and ethnically diverse patient population and a centrally managed public health-care system. * Ontario's medical devices sector employs more than 19,000 highly educated people and comprises more than 500 manufacturing companies that include global subsidiaries as well as niche-driven domestic companies. * Ontario's agricultural-biotech / [[bioproducts]] sector employs more than 6,000 people, including 700 scientists and invests $166 million annually in agricultural-food research at 12 world-class institutions. * This sector works closely with the manufacturing sector in the production of bio-chemicals and bio-fuels. * Ontario ranks in the top three jurisdictions in North America in terms of workforce and R&D expenditures in the agricultural-biotechnology sector.
'''[http://gsin.holophrasticenterprises.com/explore Explore G-SIN]'''
Finally, there are number of technology platforms scattered throughout the province of Ontario, providing world class support and infrastructure for innovative research and services in genomics and proteomics.
== See also == *Genomics Sector Innovation Network [http://www.g-sin.com/] *OGI Board Members [http://www.ontariogenomics.ca/about/board-directors] *OGI Staff [http://www.ontariogenomics.ca/about/staff]
== References == *Ontario Genomics [http://www.ontariogenomics.ca/] *Ontario Genomics: What is Genomics? [http://www.ontariogenomics.ca/about/what-genomics]
== External links == *'''Genomics Sector Innovation Network''' [http://www.g-sin.com/] *'''Ontario Network of Excellence (ONE)''' [http://www.oneinnovation.ca]
[[Category:Organizations based in Toronto]] [[Category:Genome projects]] [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Life sciences industry]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Globalization]]; added [[Category:Economic globalization]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{globalize/US|date=January 2013}} '''Global labor arbitrage''' is an economic phenomenon where, as a result of the removal of or disintegration of [[Trade barrier|barriers]] to [[international trade]], jobs move to nations where labor and the cost of doing business (such as [[Environmental law|environmental regulations]]) is inexpensive and/or impoverished labor moves to nations with higher paying jobs.<ref name=Whitney>The "global labor arbitrage" phenomenon has been described by economist [[Stephen S. Roach]]. See Mike Whitney, [http://www.entrepreneur.com/tradejournals/article/147390483.html "Labor arbitrage,"] ''Entrepreneur'', June 2006.</ref>
Two common barriers to international trade are [[tariff]]s (politically imposed) and the costs of transporting goods across oceans. With the advent of the [[Internet]], the decrease of the costs of [[telecommunications]], and the possibility of near-instantaneous document transfer, the barriers to the trade of intellectual work product, which is essentially, any kind of work that can be performed on a computer (such as [[computer programming]]) or that makes use of a college education, have been greatly reduced.
Often, a prosperous nation (such as the [[United States]]) will remove its barriers to international trade, integrating its [[labor market]] with those of nations with a lower cost of labor (such as [[India]], [[China]], and [[Mexico]]), resulting in a shifting of jobs from the prosperous nation to the developing one. The end result is an increase in the supply of labor relative to the demand for labor, which means a decrease in costs and a decrease in wages.
==Forms of global labor arbitrage== Global labor arbitrage can take many forms, including but not limited to:
===Foreign outsourcing=== {{main|Offshore outsourcing}}
Capital moves to nations with cheap labor, lower taxes and or fewer environmental regulations or other costs of doing business for the purpose of producing goods and services for export to other markets.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Miszczynski|first=Milosz|date=2016-06-22|title=Labour arbitrage: the lifecycle of a global production node|url=http://www.emeraldinsight.com/doi/abs/10.1108/JOE-04-2016-0009|journal=Journal of Organizational Ethnography|volume=5|issue=2|pages=106–122|doi=10.1108/JOE-04-2016-0009|issn=2046-6749}}</ref> The classic example is the case of a factory or office closing in Nation A and then moving to Nation B for the purpose of producing goods or services at lower labor costs for export back to Nation A's market. This can result in layoffs for workers in Nation A. For example, in the United States, the amount of manufacturing jobs has decreased while the importation of manufactured goods from other nations has increased (along with the United States' trade deficit). These trends are now affecting the service sector as well.<ref>Nadeem, S (2009) [http://nadeem.commons.gc.cuny.edu/files/2010/04/Nadeem_Global-Networks.pdf "The Uses and Abuses of Time: Globalization and Time Arbitrage in India’s Outsourcing Industries,"] ''[[Global Networks]]''.</ref>
===Importation of foreign labor using work visas=== Labor, often skilled and educated, moves to a nation on a temporary or permanent basis. This has the effect of increasing the supply of labor in that nation's market.
This type of labor importation may be advantageous. According to the National Venture Capital Association (NVCA), a registered [[political action committee]],<ref name="Open Secrets NVCA">{{cite web|title=National Venture Capital Assn|url=https://www.opensecrets.org/pacs/lookup2.php?strID=C00150367|publisher=[[Center for Responsive Politics]]|accessdate=8 June 2015|quote=FEC Committee ID: C00150367}}</ref> over 25% of all [[Startup company|startups]] responding to an NVCA survey, in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]] of the US in the last 15 years were "immigrant-founded" (most likely former or current [[H-1B]]s).<ref name = NFAP>{{cite web|last=Anderson|first=Stuart|title=American Made: The Impact of Immigrant Entrepreneurs and Professionals on U.S. Competitiveness|url=http://www.nfap.com/researchactivities/studies/immigrant_entreprenuers_professionals_november_2006.pdf|publisher=National Venture Capital Association|accessdate=22 July 2012|author2=Michaela Platzer}}</ref> 40% of all publicly traded and venture founded companies in high tech manufacturing were started by immigrants. These account for more than half of all jobs in this sector.
{{Quote box |quote = To conduct the research, we examined the Thomson Financial database of all publicly traded venture-backed companies founded since 1970. After eliminating those that had merged, been acquired, or were otherwise no longer publicly traded (or in business), we used public records, Internet research, e-mails, and phone calls to identify the nativity of the founders for the nearly 900 remaining companies.4 The companies on our final list of immigrant-founded U.S. publicly traded venture-backed companies had at least one immigrant founder. |source = National Venture Capital Association, ''American Made: The Impact of Immigrant Entrepreneurs and Professionals on U.S. Competitiveness'', Stuart Anderson and Micheala Platzer, Undated.<ref name = NFAP/> |align = none }}
Conversely, the NVCA "American Made," publication makes little mention of US born co-founders, makes an errant claim that Intel has an immigrant founder,<ref name="Grove Not a Founder"/> resulting in a faulty claim of the following companies employing more than 245,000 people in 2005:<ref name = NFAP/> * [[Intel]] (co-founders: [[Gordon Moore]]-US, [[Robert Noyce]]-US) * [[Sun Microsystems|Sun Microsystems (1982-2010)]] (co-founders: [[Vinod Khosla]]-India, [[Andy Bechtolsheim]]-Germany, [[Bill Joy]]-US, [[Scott McNealy]]-US) * [[Google]] (co-founders: [[Larry Page]]-US, [[Sergey Brin]]-Russia) * [[Yahoo!]] (co-founders: [[David Filo]]-US, [[Jerry Yan]]-Taiwan) * [[eBay]] (founder: [[Pierre Omidyar]]-France)
Previous studies authored by Stuart Anderson, of the National Foundation for American Policy,<ref>{{cite web|title=About|url=http://www.nfap.com/about/biographies/|work=Biographies|publisher=National Foundation for American Policy|accessdate=1 March 2014}}</ref> had been careful to make the distinction of, "...founded or co-founded..." whereas the National Venture Capital Association uses the term, "immigrant-founded" 55 times in its 39-page document. The publication's data tables disclose only the names of "immigrant-born founder or cofounder", American born co-founders, and the number of American co-founders, are omitted.<ref name = NFAP/> Additionally, according to [[Intel]] Corporation (99,900 employees), Hungarian born CEO [[Andy Grove]] was not an Intel co-founder.<ref name="Grove Not a Founder">{{cite web|title=Intel Facts|url=http://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/company-overview/company-facts.html|work=Answers to our most frequent questions|publisher=[[Intel]]|accessdate=1 March 2014}}</ref>
===Immigration=== Impoverished labor moves towards capital in prosperous nations. This tends to increase the supply of labor relative to capital in the prosperous nations and potentially decreases wages, according to the laws of supply and demand (of and for labor). However, this decrease can be offset by job creation due to talented immigrants, as discussed in the last section.
==See also== * [[Balance of trade]] * [[Absolute advantage]] * [[Global workforce]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
{{Globalization|state=autocollapse}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Global Labor Arbitrage}} [[Category:Arbitrage]] [[Category:International trade]] [[Category:Global workforce]] [[Category:Offshoring]] [[Category:Economic globalization]]

revision.comment: Hunter Fraud Score links added, no more orphan.
revision.text:
'''Hunter Fraud Score''' is a rating score launched locally in [[India]] by [[Credit rating agency]], [[Experian]], to detect fraud in credit applications to banks and insurance companies and help them lower their losses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.experian.co.uk/identity-and-fraud/fraud-prevention/hunter.html|title=Prevent Application Fraud {{!}} Identity & Fraud {{!}} Experian UK|website=www.experian.co.uk|access-date=2016-11-02}}</ref>
== Key features == * Screening data at first level and to identity inconsistencies * More the data is found, more are the chances of fraud level * Data sources are used which include intelligence for smart detection * Prioritising investigations depending upon fraud level.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/banking/finance/banking/experian-india-launches-new-fraud-solution-for-banking-and-insurance/articleshow/51992468.cms|title=Experian India launches new fraud solution for banking and insurance - The Economic Times|newspaper=The Economic Times|access-date=2016-11-02}}</ref> '''Closed user group (CUG)'''
Presently, [[Experian]] maintains a network of 47 banks and 15 life insurer companies as a part of the CUG, that covers 50 per cent of the retail banking applications whose data is verified timely. With increase in these numbers, it can become a more complicated and secured database.
== Methodology == There are various criteria based on which information is matched in the loan application from different data sources and inconsistencies after that are identified.The company has some sophisticated analytical solutions which allows it to create an advanced analytical approach, to predict and calculate some authentic score that can help banks lower their losses. A data repository has been created to collect the data of all the past customers in addition to their [[Know your customer|KYC]] norms data, on which data mining is performed to filter out the useful minute details and extrapolate the user's data. The solution has some customised rules to analyse different data sources to highlight inconsistencies and discrepancies so that it can match with the known fraud data. The results calculate the level of fraud risk and any application if found suspicious is moved into a special investigation tool to take further action.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mortgagestrategy.co.uk/issues/18-february-2013/the-war-on-fraud/|title=The war on fraud - Mortgage Strategy|date=2013-02-18|newspaper=Mortgage Strategy|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-11-02}}</ref>
Under Section 45 of the Insurance Laws (Amendment) Act, if three years duration is crossed for any reason to reject an insurance claim then it can not be rejected after that period. So, this repository would help them catch criminals before they breach the obstacles to commit fraud. Data from life insurers reveals that there is about 20 per cent rise year by year in fraudulent claims.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/finance/experian-s-data-repository-to-do-micro-segment-scrutiny-to-prevent-life-insurance-frauds-115090400777_1.html|title=Experian's Hunter to detect life insurance fraud|last=Saraswathy|first=M.|date=2015-09-05|newspaper=Business Standard India|access-date=2016-11-02}}</ref> A nexus has been identified of fraudulent people who get their claims passed through their relatives in the authorities which pass the claims. Depending on the screening, businesses will be able to identify applications that have high probability of potential fraud.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/Experian-launches-credit-monitor-Hunter-Fraud-Score/articleshow/51993403.cms|title=Experian launches credit monitor Hunter Fraud Score - Times of India|newspaper=The Times of India|access-date=2016-11-02}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Market research]] [[Category:Credit rating agencies in India]]

revision.comment: Undid revision 870835087 by [[Special:Contributions/62.80.168.190|62.80.168.190]] ([[User talk:62.80.168.190|talk] Synchronize information with the Ukrainian version of Wikipedia.])
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox Officeholder |name = Igor Mazepa
{{small|Ігор Мазепа}} |image = IND 9877.jpg | occupation = Director general of [[Concorde Capital]] investment company{{cite web|title=Leaders|url=http://concorde.ua/en/about/leaders/}} }} '''Igor Aleksandrovich Mazepa''' ({{lang-uk|Мазе́па І́гор Олекса́ндрович}}; born 02 Jule 1976) is the director general of the [[Concorde Capital]] investment company in ([[Ukraine]], [[Kiev]]).{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/b/ed480f92-2570-4429-9fca-223c0f3107cd|title=Business Leaders Urge Russia-Ukraine Talks: Mazepa|date=25 Aug 2015|accessdate=22 Feb 2016|agency=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]}}{{cite news|url=http://interfax.com.ua/news/interview/57396.html|title=Конкорд Капитал: 2012 год станет переломным для выхода крупнейших украинских компаний на внешний рынок|date=30 Dec 2010|accessdate=22 Feb 2016|agency=[[Interfax-Ukraine]] |language=Russian}}{{cite news|url=http://forbes.net.ua/business/1401317-igor-mazepa-my-uzhe-prohodim-dno|title=Игорь Мазепа: Мы уже проходим дно|date=7 Sep 2015|accessdate=22 Feb 2016|agency=[[Forbes|Forbes Media LLC]] |language=Russian}} ==Biography== He graduated from [[Kyiv National Economic University]] having completed graduation programs in International Economics and Law. In 1997 he started his career of investment banker in Russian – American Investment Company Prospect Investments. In 2000—2002 he worked in the position of Managing Director at IC Foyil Securities New Europe, and then as director of IC IFC (International Financial Corporation). In 2004 he founded and became Director General of IC [[Concorde Capital]].{{cite news|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/ukraine-politics/term-ukraine-restore-cooperation-imf-two-months-says-concorde-capital.html|title=Term for Ukraine to restore cooperation with IMF is two months, says Concorde Capital|date=23 May 2018}} Many years the company retains the position of one of three best investment banks of Ukraine (according to the largest international information agency [[Thomson Reuters]]).{{cite news|url=http://delo.ua/finance/thomson-reuters-opredelil-luchshie-brokerskie-kompanii-ukrainy-v-239476|title=Thomson Reuters определил лучшие брокерские компании Украины в 2014 году|date=19 Jun 2014|accessdate=22 Feb 2016|agency=Дело |language=Russian}} In 2008 he was elected as Chairman of the exchange committee of the [[Ukrainian Exchange]], and at present he continues to act in this capacity.{{cite news|url=http://finance.liga.net/banks/2014/7/15/news/39297.htm|title=Игорь Мазепа вошел в состав набсовета Альфа-Банка|date=15 Jul 2014|accessdate=22 Feb 2016|agency=ЛIГАБiзнесIнформ |language=Russian}}{{cite news|url=http://www.ux.ua/a508/?nt=101|title=Игорь Мазепа избран Председателем Биржевого совета|date=23 Nov 2008|accessdate=22 Feb 2016|agency=[[Ukrainian Exchange]] |language=Russian}} In July–September 2014 he acted as a member of the Supervisory Committee of PJSC Alfa-Bank.{{cite news|url=http://delo.ua/finance/ukreksimbank-ne-dolzhen-byt-karmannym-bankom-pravitelstva-igo-280577/|title=Укрэксимбанк не должен быть карманным банком правительства — Игорь Мазепа|date=14 Oct 2014|accessdate=22 Feb 2016|agency=Дело |language=Russian}} In 2010 he participated in the project of [[ICTV (Ukraine)|ICTV channel]] “Ukrainian Dream” as one of investors of promising business ideas of common Ukrainians.{{cite news|url=http://delo.ua/ukrainian-dream/investiciju-v-50-tysjach-v-proekt-147778/|title=Инвестицию в 50 тысяч в проекте "Украинская мечта" на ICTV виграла репетитор из Полтавы (ВИДЕО)|date=17 Nov 2010|accessdate=22 Feb 2016|agency=Дело |language=Russian}} The best manager in the exchange market of Ukraine as ranked by the publishing house “Economics”, in 2007- winner in the nomination “Personality of the exchange market of Ukraine”{{cite news|url=http://www.business.ua/i795/a24312/ |title=Финансовый Оскар-2007 |publisher=Блиц-Информ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080730052825/http://www.business.ua/i795/a24312 |archivedate=30 July 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news|url=https://www.aval.ua/ru/press/media/?id=47021|title=Финансовый Оскар-2007// Бизнес.|date=23 Apr 2008|accessdate=22 Feb 2016|agency=Aval |language=Russian}} of the financial rating of Business magazine.
Igor Mazepa's business name was involved in numerous scandals.[https://www.capital.ua/ru/publication/104621-privatnaya-piramida-igorya-mazepy The personal pyramid of Igor Mazepa In 2015 Igor Mazepa's corporation Concorde Capital founded a forex broker Private FX, which became a technical successor of the scandalously ruined financial pyramid Forex Trend Limited developed in 2011 by the arrested financial criminal Pavel Krymov https://www.rbc.ru/magazine/2018/11/5bc4bfa49a7947a0aed6a006 РБК: Одна из крупнейших афер на рынке Forex [http://vlasti.net/news/277973 Организатор финансовых пирамид Forex Trend и Private FX – Павел Геннадьевич Крымов]. The information about Igor Mazepa's 100% stake in the capital of the Private FX{{cite web|url=https://archive.li/8LiBO|title="Інформація для клієнтів Private FX на сайті Concorde Capital".}} was publicly confirmed by CEO of PrivateFX Alexander Bykov [https://youtube.com/watch?v=XppxE_ZPZn0&t=21m48s СЕО PrivateFX Александр Быков на презентации 29 мая 2016]. In April 2017 Igor Mazepa made a technical sale of Private FX to the unknown front company Prime Broker, without having closed the obligations to investors for almost $18 Millions {{cite web|url=https://gazeta.ua/ru/articles/economics/_igor-mazepa-bolshe-ne-akcioner-kompanii-privatefx/766750|title="Игорь Мазепа больше не акционер компании PrivateFX".}}. {{Cite news|url=https://gazeta.ua/articles/economics/_igor-mazepa-ignoruye-svoyih-kliyentiv-iz-privatefx/832114|title=Ігор Мазепа ігнорує своїх клієнтів із PrivateFX|last=Gazeta.ua|date=2018-04-16|language=uk-UA|work=Gazeta.ua|accessdate=2018-06-25}} The websites of both companies are no longer accessible and the investors have not received any refund. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mazepa, Igor}} [[Category:1976 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Ukrainian businesspeople]] [[Category:Kyiv National Economic University alumni]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder |image = |imagesize = 150px | |name = Isha Johansen |nationality = Sierra Leonean ||order = President of the [[Sierra Leone Football Association]] |term_start = August 3, 2013 |term_end = |predecessor1 =[[Nahim Khadi]] |birth_date = |birth_place = [[Freetown]], [[Sierra Leone]] |birth_name = Isha Tejan-Cole |dead = |ethnicity = |party = |spouse = Arne Birger Johansen |residence = [[Freetown]], [[Sierra Leone]]
[[Chelsea, London]] |religion = |ethnic group = }} '''Isha Tejan-Cole Johansen''' (born c. 1965{{cite web |url=http://venturesafrica.com/the-sierra-leonean-entrepreneur-and-football-enthusiast-isha-johansen/ |title=Meet Isha Johansen - Sierra Leonean Entrepreneur and Football Enthusiast |author=OluwaBusayo Sotunde |date=October 10, 2012 |website=venturesafrica.com |quote=The 47-year old business savvy entrepreneur ...}}) is a [[Sierra Leone]]an [[entrepreneur]] and the current president of the [[Sierra Leone Football Association]]. Johansen is one of only a few women in the world to have headed a national football association,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23560252|title=BBC Sport - Johansen confirmed as SLFA president|author=Mohamed Fajah Barrie|work=BBC Sport}} along with [[Lydia Nsekera]], the former president of the Burundi football association, [[Izetta Sombo Wesley]], the former leader of the [[Liberia Football Association]] and [[Sonia Bien-Aime]] of the [[Turks and Caicos Islands Football Association]].{{cite news |url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/soccer/sierra-leone-football-association-to-have-first-female-president/ |title=Johansen to be first female president of SLAFA |date=August 2, 2013 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |website=sportsnet.ca}} Isha Johansen is the owner and [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of [[Sierra Leone National Premier League]] club [[F.C. Johansen]]. ==Early life and family== Isha Johansen was born as Isha Tejan-Cole in [[Freetown]], [[Sierra Leone]], into the Tejan-Cole family, who are of [[Oku people (Sierra Leone)|Aku]] or [[Sierra Leone Creole|Creole]] descent. She was immersed in football from the very beginning, as her father co-founded [[East End Lions F.C.]] in Freetown.{{cite news |title=Sierra Leone's FA president Isha Johansen: Meet Africa's most powerful woman in football |author=Lydia Smith |newspaper=[[International Business Times]] |date=November 21, 2015 |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/sierra-leones-fa-president-isha-johansen-meet-africas-most-powerful-woman-football-1529757}} Her father took her to see football matches, and she played football with her brothers and their friends. She was educated at a convent school in Freeport and a boarding school in [[Yeovil]], England.{{cite news |title=Sierra Leone's Isha Johansen blazes trail amid tragedy and infighting |author=Anna Kessel |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=January 24, 2015 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/jan/24/sierra-leone-isha-johansen-ebola-sexism}} She was raised in a religious [[Muslim]] family. She is married to the [[Norway|Norwegian]] Consul in Sierra Leone, Arne Birger Johansen. ==Football== Isha Johansen founded her own football club, [[F.C. Johansen]], in 2004. The club was started with the objective of giving guidance and opportunities to children whose lives had been disrupted by the recent [[Sierra Leone Civil War]] (1991-2002). It began playing in Division One in 2011 and was promoted to the Premier League the following year. Johansen was elected president of the Sierra Leone Football Association (SLFA) unopposed on 3 August 2013,{{cite web|url=http://africayoungvoices.com/2013/08/isha-johansen-becomes-first-woman-slfa-president/|title=ISHA JOHANSEN becomes first woman SLFA President|work=africayoungvoices.com}} after her main opponent, former Sierra Leone international footballer [[Mohamed Kallon]] was disqualified by the Sierra Leone Football Executive committee for not meeting the SLFA [[residency (domicile)|residency]] requirement in the country.{{cite web|url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/sports/summer/football/1015306-fresh-turmoil-in-sierra-leone-football-elections-as-former-player-kallon-disqualified|title=Fresh turmoil in Sierra Leone football elections as former player Kallon disqualified|work=insidethegames.biz}}{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201308010912.html|title=allAfrica.com: Sierra Leone: Kallon, Rodney React to SLFA Disqualification|work=allAfrica.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23549250|title=BBC Sport - Fifa endorses decision to ban Kallon from SLFA election|author=Mohamed Fajah Barrie|work=BBC Sport}} Kallon appealed his disqualification, but the [[FIFA]] delegation to Freetown confirmed the disqualifications of Kallon and two other candidates (for links to gambling), so Johansen was unopposed. When [[Sepp Blatter]] was pressured to step down as head of FIFA, Johansen was touted as a possible successor in the press.{{cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/06/03/football/fifa-sepp-blatter-football-isa-johansen/ |title=FIFA elections: Should football elect a woman to replace Sepp Blatter? |author=James Masters |date=February 4, 2016 |publisher=[[CNN]]}}{{cite web |url=http://www.eurosport.com/football/why-can-t-isha-johansen-be-fifa-s-first-female-president_sto4993593/story.shtml |title=Why can't Isha Johansen be FIFA's first female president? |author=Desmond Kane |date=November 18, 2015 |publisher=[[Eurosport]]}} She launched Powerplay, an initiative to encourage women and girls to play the game and to help empower them. It has the support of FIFA and the [[Confederation of African Football]]. She also started the annual African International Youth Tournament in 2009. On 7 September 2016, SLFA President Isha Johansen, Vice President Brima Kamara and Secretary General Christopher Kamara were jailed by the Anti-corruption Commission for failing to provide reports regarding the SLFA's financial statements and the use of money.{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-leone-football-corruption-idUKKCN11E02I |title=Sierra Leone Football Association officials arrested by anti-graft agency |author= Umaru Fofana |date=8 September 2016 |agency=[[Reuters]]}} The trio were released after posting bail.{{cite news |url=http://www.espnfc.us/sierra-leone/story/2946073/top-sierra-leone-fa-officials-spend-night-in-jail-in-corruption-investigation |title=Top Sierra Leone FA officials spend night in jail in corruption investigation |date=8 September 2016 |agency=[[Associated Press]]}} FIFA defended the SLFA in a letter, stating, "FIFA has no reason to suspect there has been misuse of funds that FIFA has provided to the SLFA", having audited the SLFA's accounts earlier in the year.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37432190 |title=Fifa backs Sierra Leone FA in use of funds |date=21 September 2016 |publisher=BBC News}} ==Other activities== In 1993, she became the first woman publisher in the country's history, producing ''Rapture Magazine'', an entertainment publication. She was also contributing editor to ''Ovation'' magazine. She founded the Pink Charity Fund to combat [[breast cancer]] in 2006 and the Women of Excellence Awards. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Johansen, Isha}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Sierra Leonean businesspeople]] [[Category:Sierra Leonean women in business]] [[Category:Association football executives]] [[Category:Football people in Sierra Leone]]

revision.text:
{{Use Australian English|date=September 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Ita Buttrose | image = Ita Buttrose 2014.jpg | caption = Buttrose in June 2014 | birth_name = Ita Clare Buttrose | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1942|1|17}} | birth_place = [[Sydney]], [[New South Wales]] | nationality = Australian | occupation = Magazine editor, fashion journalist, media personality, ambassador | television = ''[[Today Extra]]'' | spouse = | children = 2 | title = Editor of ''[[The Australian Women's Weekly]]'' }} '''Ita Clare Buttrose''' (first name rhymes with 'fighter'{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oKgcspZP7FA|title=Ita Buttrose, This Is Your Life Part 1|first=|last=Studio 10|date=16 January 2017|publisher=|via=YouTube}}) [[Officer of the Order of Australia|AO]] [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire|OBE]] (born 17 January 1942) is an Australian journalist, businesswoman, television personality and author. She was the founding editor of ''[[Cleo (magazine)|Cleo]]'', a high-circulation magazine aimed at women aged 20 to 40 that was frank about sexuality (and, in its infancy, featured nude male centrefolds) and, later, as the editor of the more conventional ''[[Australian Women's Weekly]]''. She is the youngest person ever to be appointed editor of the ''Weekly'', which was then, per capita, the largest-selling magazine in the world.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}} [[File:Ita Buttrose and Ross Steele AACTA 2012 (1).jpg|thumb||Ita Buttrose at the [[AACTA Awards]]]] Buttrose was a panelist on the [[Network Ten]] morning program ''[[Studio 10]]'' from 2013 until 2018.[http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/tv/ita-buttrose-still-bringing-it-at-71/story-e6frfmyi-1226748976523 "Ita Buttrose still bringing it in at 71"], ''News.com.au'' (Australia), 29 June 2014. ==Early life== Buttrose was born at [[Potts Point]], Sydney,{{cite web|title=Ita Buttrose|url=http://www.abc.net.au/tv/talkingheads/txt/s2186115.htm|website=[[Talking Heads (Australian TV series)|Talking Heads]]|publisher=ABC|accessdate=26 November 2015|date=17 March 2008}} and named after her maternal grandmother, Ita Clare Rodgers (née Rosenthal). She was raised as a Catholic by her parents.Pitt, Helen. (10 April 2011). "Girl talk: Cover story". ''[[The Sun-Herald]]'', Sydney. p. 12. Buttrose's father, Charles Oswald, was a journalist and at one time the editor of ''[[The Daily Mirror (Sydney)|The Daily Mirror]]'' in Sydney. By her own account she had decided on a career in journalism at the age of 11.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/tv/enoughrope/transcripts/s1137508.htm|title=''Enough Rope'', 21 June 2004, interview transcript|publisher=}} Buttrose spent her first five years in [[New York City]] when her father was the New York correspondent for ''[[The Daily Mirror (Australia)|The Daily Mirror]]''.[http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/lifestyle/people/ita-buttrose-on-kickstarting-a-sexual-revolution-20110411-1d9zg.html Helen Pitt, "Ita Buttrose on kick-starting a sexual revolution", ''Brisbane Times'', 11 April 2011] The family returned to Australia in 1949 and settled in the harbourside suburb of [[Vaucluse, New South Wales|Vaucluse]]. Her parents divorced during her teens, after 25 years of marriage, and details of her father's private life were printed in the tabloid press, causing considerable anguish to her mother. Buttrose briefly attended a private school but because her father could not afford the fees she was then moved to a public school. She completed her secondary education at Dover Heights Home Science High School, leaving at 15 to begin her career. She started her career at [[Australian Consolidated Press]], owned by the Packer family, working as a copy girl at the ''[[Australian Women's Weekly]]'', then became a cadet journalist on ''[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]'' and ''[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Sunday Telegraph]]'' in Sydney. Her first byline came in 1959 when the 17-year-old covered the Australian tour by [[Princess Alexandra, The Honourable Lady Ogilvy|Princess Alexandra]].{{cite news|last=Heaney|first=Claire|title=Women to take poll position|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/business/women-to-take-poll-position-for-survey/story-fn7j19iv-1226149384296|accessdate=24 April 2012|newspaper=Herald Sun}} ==Career== At 21 years of age, Buttrose married architect Alasdair "Mac" Macdonald and had two children. She was appointed women's editor of the ''Telegraph'' at just 23 years old. In 1966 she won a racetrack fashion contest run by a rival newspaper, for which the first prize was an overseas trip, including a visit to [[Expo 67]] in Montreal. Buttrose and her husband then stopped in England in 1967 where she worked for a time on the British national magazine ''[[Woman's Own]]'' before giving birth to her first child, a daughter, Kate. It was after her daughter's birth that she received a [[telegram]] from [[Sir Frank Packer]], head of Australian Consolidated Press, offering her back her former job as women's editor at the ''Telegraph''. The family then returned to Australia. In 1971 Buttrose was chosen as founding editor of a new Australian women's magazine.[http://www.australianoftheyear.org.au/honour-roll/#browse:view=fullView&recipientID=937 ''Australian of the Year 2013'', www.australianoftheyear.org.au] Retrieved on 24 March 2015 This was originally to have been an Australian edition of the renowned American magazine ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]'', but the deal fell through after [[William Randolph Hearst|Hearst]] Magazines sold the ''Cosmopolitan'' rights to longtime Packer rivals [[Fairfax Media|Fairfax]], so Packer and Buttrose set about creating a new publication, dubbed ''[[Cleo (magazine)|Cleo]]'', which they launched in 1972, several months ahead of its rival. ''Cleo'' was an instant hit, selling its entire original print run in just two days; the magazine broke new ground in Australian mainstream publishing, featuring the first nude male [[centrefold]] (actor [[Jack Thompson (actor)|Jack Thompson]]) and frank articles on female sexuality and other topics, leading to the inclusion of the first sealed section in an Australian magazine. During the early months of the magazine, Buttrose became pregnant with her second child, Ben, but with the grudging support of the Packers she worked through her pregnancy; an unusual feat for that time as it was still common for women to have to give up work permanently after they became pregnant. {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c1C-22Zy0Ec|title=Ita Buttrose Pt2: 'Paper Giants' – the birth of Cleo, Life Matters, ABC Radio National|publisher=YouTube}} Buttrose edited ''Cleo'' until 1975, when she was appointed editor of the Packers' flagship magazine, ''[[The Australian Women's Weekly]]'' (1975–76), then she became editor-in-chief of both publications from 1976–78, before being appointed Publisher of Australian Consolidated Press Women's Division from 1978–81. In 1981 she left the Packers after their rival [[Rupert Murdoch]] offered her the job of Editor-in-Chief of the ''Daily Telegraph'' and ''Sunday Telegraph'' in 1981, making her the first female editor of a major metropolitan newspaper in Australia, a position she held until 1984; she was also appointed to the board of [[News Limited]]. She made frequent appearances on radio and TV and in 1980, her media prominence led to her becoming the subject of the song "[[Ita (song)|Ita]]", recorded by rock band [[Cold Chisel]], which was included on their successful ''[[East (Cold Chisel album)|East]]'' album. Buttrose was the chairperson of the National Advisory Committee on AIDS (NACAIDS) from 1984 until 1988.{{Citation|title=Buttrose, Ita (1942–)|journal=Trove | publication-date=2008|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.party-487813|accessdate=2012-02-26}} On one occasion, she appeared personally in a nationwide TV campaign to explain that ''donating'' blood at a blood bank did not pose a risk of catching AIDS (the fear of which had caused a significant drop in donations). Instantly recognisable by her slight lisp, cultured mode of speech and immaculate appearance, Buttrose became a household name in the 1970s and 1980s, and she was frequently parodied by Australian TV comedians including [[Paul Hogan]] and [[Jane Turner]]. After her stint with News Limited, Buttrose founded her own publishing company, Capricorn Publishing, and launched her own magazine, ''Ita'', but this eventually folded, and she launched a new company, The Good Life Publishing Company, which in 2005 published ''bark!'', a lifestyle magazine aimed at dog owners.{{cite web|url=http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/3507369|title=National Library of Australia catalogue: Bark!|publisher=National Library of Australia|accessdate=2012-02-26}} [[File:Ita Buttrose.jpg|thumb|left|Ita Buttrose at ''[[La Traviata]]'' at Handa Opera on Sydney Harbour 2012]] === Author === Buttrose is also a prolific author and has published nine books, including her autobiography, ''A Passionate Life''. In 2011 Penguin published ''A Guide to Australian Etiquette''. === Television === On 9 June 2013 at 71 years of age, Buttrose joined [[Network Ten]] where she hosted morning program ''[[Studio 10]]'' two mornings a week for the station alongside [[Joe Hildebrand]], [[Sarah Harris (journalist)|Sarah Harris]], [[Denise Drysdale]] and [[Jessica Rowe]]. The show premiered in late 2013.[http://www.news.com.au/breaking-news/national/ita-buttrose-joins-tens-morning-show/story-e6frfku9-1226660775254 Ita Buttrose joins Ten's morning show], news.com.au, 9 June 2013 However, 2016 saw Buttrose reduce her appearances on the program to just twice a week to spend more time with her grandchildren. Prior to joining [[Network Ten]], Buttrose was a regular commentator on the [[Nine Network]] breakfast show ''[[Today (Australian TV program)|Today]]'' and was at one point considered to replace [[Kerri-Anne Kennerley]] in the network's morning slot.[http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/sydney-confidential/nine-wants-an-early-ita-buttrose-for-kerri-anne-kennerleys-mornng-show/story-e6frewz0-1226173492155?nk=4f709d0e67be4f3e689f87bf3d801737 Nine wants an early Ita Buttrose for Kerri Anne Kennerleys morning slot ], news.com.au, 22 October 2011 Buttrose was also a regular on [[Beauty and the Beast (talk show)|''Beauty and the Beast'']] in the 1990s and early 2000s. [[File:Ita Buttrose (11024358813).jpg|thumb|Ita Buttrose at the premiere of ''[[Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues]]'']] In April 2018, Buttrose resigned as panelist on ''[[Studio 10]]'' to focus on other parts of her life, including spending more time with her grandchildren and writing.{{Cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/tv/morning-shows/ita-buttrose-to-depart-studio-10-tomorrow-reports/news-story/1a3d76973e50f1336a5994747c67e576|title=Ita Buttrose to depart Studio 10|work=NewsComAu|access-date=2018-04-24}} Since leaving [[Network Ten]], Buttrose has appeared on [[The Morning Show (TV program)|''The Morning Show'']] on the Seven Network and filled in for [[Sonia Kruger]] on ''[[Today Extra]]'' on the [[Nine Network]]. == Honours and legacy == Buttrose was made an [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] (OBE) in 1979,[http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=1107556&search_type=quick&showInd=true It's an Honour] – Officer of the Order of the British Empire and became an [[Officer of the Order of Australia]] (AO) in 1988.[http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=872553&search_type=quick&showInd=true It's an Honour] – Officer of the Order of Australia In 2003, she was awarded the [[Centenary Medal]].[http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=1126678&search_type=quick&showInd=true It's an Honour] – Centenary Medal Buttrose was inducted to the [[Victorian Honour Roll of Women]] in 2001. In 1984 she was named the Variety Club 'Personality of the Year' as well as winning the Australasian Academy of Broadcast, Arts and Sciences for the 'Most Promising Newcomer to Radio'. In 1993 Buttrose was named Juvenile Diabetes Foundation's 'Australian of the Year'. In 2011 she was elected President of Alzheimer's Australia until end of June 2014. She is currently an ambassador for Alzheimer's Australia. In January 2013, Buttrose was named the 2013 [[Australian of the Year]]. She was awarded an honorary [[Doctor of Letters]] degree by [[Macquarie University]] in 2014 in recognition of her contribution to the arts. In 2015, she was awarded a second honorary Doctor of Letters degree by the [[University of Wollongong]] for her distinguished service to Australian society and for her commitment to advocating for vulnerable people in the community. Among her many other public service and charitable activities, Buttrose is a patron of Women of Vision, World Vision Australia, the University of Third Age, the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation of Australia, Amarant, the National Menopause Foundation, the Sydney Women's Festival, Safety House and the National Institute of Secretaries and Administrators. Buttrose is an ambassador of the Australian Women Chamber of Commerce (AWCCI) and sits on the AWCCI Advisory Board. She works on the professional speakers' circuit, and is associated with the Ovation Channel.{{cite web|url=http://www.awcci.org.au/AboutUs/AdvisoryCommittee/tabid/68/Default.aspx|title=Advisory Committee|work=www.awcci.org.au|publisher=[[Australian Women Chamber of Commerce & Industry]]|accessdate=2012-02-26|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309121128/http://www.awcci.org.au/AboutUs/AdvisoryCommittee/tabid/68/Default.aspx|archivedate=9 March 2012|df=dmy-all}} ===''Paper Giants''=== In April 2011, Buttrose and ''Cleo'' were the subject of the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC-TV]] two-part [[telemovie]] ''[[Paper Giants: The Birth of Cleo]]'', starring [[Asher Keddie]] as Buttrose, [[Rob Carlton]] as Kerry Packer and [[Tony Barry]] as Frank Packer.[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1724700/ IMDb – ''Paper Giants: The Birth of Cleo''] ==Personal life== In 1975, While editing the ''Women's Weekly'' Buttrose's first marriage to Alasdair "Mac" Macdonald broke down and the couple divorced in 1976. Later she met Peter Sawyer and they married in 1979. By her own account it was "not a very happy marriage"; Sawyer left in 1980 and they subsequently divorced. Buttrose cared for her father after he was diagnosed with [[vascular dementia]], he passed away in 1999.{{Cite book|title=Understanding Alzheimer's: the complete Australian guide to the management and prevention of Alzheimer's|last=Martins|first=Ralph|last2=Ragg|first2=Mark|publisher=Pan Macmillan Australia|year=2013|isbn=9781742611983|location=Sydney|pages=ix|chapter=Foreword}} In his 2007 book ''Who Killed Channel Nine?'', former Nine Network producer [[Gerald Stone]] claimed that Buttrose and Kerry Packer conducted a private but intense affair during Buttrose's tenure on ''Cleo'' and that Packer reportedly even offered to marry her, but she rejected the idea and they split after a "blazing row". Buttrose herself has repeatedly declined to comment on the matter.[http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/sydney-nsw/itas-volatile-affair-with-packer/story-e6freuzi-1111113909532 Sharri Markson and Sarah Blake, "Ita's volatile affair with Packer", ''Sydney Daily Telegraph'', 8 July 2007.] Buttrose resides in Sydney. ==Bibliography== Buttrose has authored or co-authored 10 books: * ''A Guide to Australian Etiquette'' (2011) * ''Eating for Eye Health: the Macular Degeneration Cookbook'', co-authored with Sydney chef Vanessa Jones (2009) * ''Get in Shape: A complete workout for strength, health & vitality'', co-authored with Lee Campbell (2007) * ''Motherguilt: Australian women reveal their true feelings about Motherhood'', co-authored with Dr Penny Adams (2005; reprinted 2006) * ''How Much Is Enough? Your Financial Roadmap To A Happy Retirement'', co- authored with Will Buttrose and Mike Galgut (2003) * ''What is Love?'' (2000) * ''A Word to the Wise'' (1999) * ''A Passionate Life'' (1998; updated paperback version published 2001) * ''Every Occasion: The Guide to Modern Etiquette'' (1985) * ''Early Edition: My First Forty Years'' (1985) === Chapter profile === * "Ita Buttrose AO, OBE: Journalist, businesswoman, television personality and author", pp. [52]-55, in: ''The world we see: leadership lessons from Australia's iconic change makers'', Sarah Liu, 2016 ({{ISBN|9780646958804}}) === Introductions === * Foreword: Martins, Ralph and Ragg, Mark. ''Understanding Alzheimer's: the complete Australian guide to the management and prevention of Alzheimer's'' (2013, Pan Macmillan Australia). ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{s-start}} {{s-media}} {{s-bef | before = Program started }} {{s-ttl | title = ''[[Studio 10]]''
Co-host with [[Joe Hildebrand]] & [[Sarah Harris (journalist)|Sarah Harris]] | years = 4 November 2013 – 25 April 2018 }} {{s-aft | after = [[Denise Scott]] }} {{s-ach}} {{s-bef | before = [[Geoffrey Rush]] }} {{s-ttl | title = [[Australian of the Year]] | years = 2013 }} {{s-aft | after = [[Adam Goodes]] }} {{s-end}} ==External links== {{commonscatinline}} * [http://www.womenaustralia.info/biogs/IMP0219b.htm National Foundation of Australian Women Archives Project biography] * [http://www.womenaustralia.info/leaders/biogs/WLE0683b.htm Buttrose, Ita Clare (1942–)] in ''The Encyclopedia of Women and Leadership in Twentieth-Century Australia'' {{Australians of the Year}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Buttrose, Ita}} [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:Australian businesspeople]] [[Category:Australian journalists]] [[Category:Australian magazine editors]] [[Category:Australian radio personalities]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Officers of the Order of Australia]] [[Category:Australian Officers of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Recipients of the Centenary Medal]] [[Category:Founders]] [[Category:Australian women in business]] [[Category:Australian of the Year Award winners]] [[Category:Women founders]]

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Johnny Kitagawa
{{Nihongo2|ジャニー喜多川}} | image = | alt = | caption = | image_size = | background = non_performing_personnel | birth_name = John Hiromu Kitagawa | alias = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1931|10|23}} | death_date = | birth_place = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] | instrument = | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[electronic dance]] | occupation = [[Record producer]] | years_active = 1968–present | label = | associated_acts = [[Johnnys]], [[Tanokin Trio]], [[Four Leaves]], [[Shonentai]], [[Hey! Say! JUMP]], [[SMAP]], [[News (band)|NEWS]], [[V6 (band)|V6]], [[Arashi]], [[Tackey & Tsubasa]], [[KAT-TUN]], [[KinKi Kids]], [[Tokio (band)|Tokio]], [[Kanjani8]], [[NYC (band)|NYC]], [[Kis-My-Ft2]], [[Sexy Zone]], [[A.B.C-Z]], [[Johnny's WEST]], [[King & Prince]] | website = {{Url|www.johnnys-net.jp}} }} {{nihongo|'''Johnny Hiromu Kitagawa'''|ジャニー喜多川|Janī Kitagawa|born {{Nihongo|John Hiromu Kitagawa|喜多川 擴|Kitagawa Hiromu}} on October 23, 1928}}, is a Japanese-American businessman and talent manager. He is the founder and president of [[Johnny & Associates]], a production agency for numerous popular [[boy band]]s in Japan. Kitagawa assembled, produced and managed more than a dozen popular bands, including [[Tanokin Trio]], [[Hey! Say! JUMP]], [[SMAP]], [[Arashi]], [[Kanjani8]], [[V6 (band)|V6]], [[News (band)|NEWS]] and [[KAT-TUN]]. Kitagawa's influence has spread beyond music to the realms of theatre and television. Regarded as one of the most powerful figures in the Japanese entertainment industry, he has held a virtual monopoly on the creation of boy bands in Japan for more than 40 years. From 1988 to 2000, Kitagawa was the subject of a number of claims that he had taken advantage of his position to engage in improper sexual relationships with boys under contract to his talent agency. Kitagawa denied these claims, and in 2002 was awarded an 8.8 million [[Japanese yen|yen]] judgment against the magazine that had published such allegations. An appeal by the magazine followed, resulting in a partial reversal of the judgment. The Tokyo High Court reduced the damages to ¥1.2 million, concluding that the reports of drinking and smoking were defamatory but that the allegations of sexual exploitation of adolescent boys by Johnny Kitagawa were true. A 2004 appeal to the Supreme Court by Kitagawa was rejected. ==Early life== Born in 1928 in [[Los Angeles, California]], United States, Kitagawa returned with his family to Japan in 1933. His father Taido was a Buddhist priest and was the third head bishop of the [[Koyasan Buddhist Temple]] in [[Little Tokyo, Los Angeles|Little Tokyo]] from 1924 to 1933.Kazahaya, Katsuichi. (1974) ''Koyasan Beikoku Betsuin 50 nen shi. pp. 138-9.'' Johnny went to America about 1949. In the early 1950s, he returned to Japan to work at the [[Embassy of the United States in Tokyo|United States Embassy]]. While walking through Tokyo's [[Yoyogi Park]] he encountered a group of boys playing baseball. He recruited them to form a singing group, acting as their manager. He named the group "[[Johnnys|The Johnnies]]". The Johnnies achieved a measure of success by using a then-novel formula of mixing attractive performers singing popular music with coordinated dance routines. The Johnnies were the first all-male pop group in Japan, and set the pattern that Kitagawa would follow with his subsequent acts. Indeed, the term "Johnnies" would come to apply generically to any of the performers under Kitagawa's employ. ==Major success== In 1968, Kitagawa achieved wider success with a four-member boy band known as {{nihongo|[[Four Leaves]]|フォーリーブス|Fō Rībusu}}. The song and dance group met with success, as reflected by seven consecutive appearances on the annual invitation-only {{nihongo|[[Kōhaku Uta Gassen]]|紅白歌合戦|Red White Song Battle}}, beginning in 1970.{{cite web|url=http://www.japan-zone.com/news/2009/01/19/four_leaves_taabo_battling_cancer.shtml|title=Four Leaves Taabo battling cancer|accessdate=5 Feb 2009|work=Japan Zone|date=19 Jan 2009}} Four Leaves performed together for ten years before disbanding in 1978. Later, in 2002, Kitagawa oversaw the band's reunion. Kitagawa went on to assemble, produce and manage many of the top all-male bands in the country, including groups such as [[Hey! Say! JUMP]], [[SMAP]], [[Tokio (band)|Tokio]], [[V6 (band)|V6]], [[Arashi]], [[Tackey & Tsubasa]], [[Kanjani8]], [[News (band)|NEWS]], [[KAT-TUN]], [[KinKi Kids]] and among many others.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2005/aug/21/popandrock3|title=J-Pop's dream factory|author=Chris Campion|work=[[The Guardian]] Music Observer Monthly|publicationdate=21 Aug 2005|accessdate=2 Feb 2009 | location=London | date=2005-08-21}} Kitagawa was able to expand his sphere of influence to include television, as his performers regularly appear on television, with many appearing on their own variety programs. They also regularly act as pitchmen for commercial products, and appear in movies. The success of Kitagawa's performers led to increased profitability, as Johnny & Associates generated 2.9 billion yen in annual profits at the height of the boy band boom. During 1997, performers belonging to the talent agency appeared in more than 40 television programs and another 40 commercials. The success of his company has made Kitagawa one of the richest men in Japan. ==The formula== Kitagawa repeatedly has employed a standard formula in the development and marketing of his acts.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/feb/11/turning-japanese-music-moguls|accessdate=23 Mar 2009|title=Turning Japanese: The seedy underworld of music moguls|work = [[The Guardian]]|author = Alex Hoban|date=11 Feb 2009 | location=London}} Johnny & Associates holds open tryouts for potential performers. The production agency recruits boys as young as ten into a talent pool known as [[Johnny's Juniors]]. Successful applicants live in a company dormitory and attend a company-run school. They train to hone their showmanship in the form of singing, dancing and acting.{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/jan/28/entertainment/ca-nino28|accessdate=16 Nov 2010|work = [[The Los Angeles Times]]|author=Bruce Wallace|date=28 Jan 2007|title=The story is written on this actor's face}} Kitagawa holds an annual summer festival known as "Johnny's Summary". {{quote box |width=25em | |align=right | quote=I'm not very interested in records. Once you release a record, you have to sell that record. You have to push one song only. You can't think of anything else. It's not good for the artist.|salign=right|source=—Johnny Kitagawa, June 1996}}Promising members of [[Johnny's Jr.]] appear alongside of established members of Kitagawa's fold. The junior members act as background dancers for the major acts to allow for name recognition prior to being launched as a separate group. The members of the Juniors also appear in on "Hachi-ji da J", a weekly television variety show. Members sing, dance, and perform in comedic sketches as they further develop the skills to graduate to a major act.{{cite web|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fl19990915pb.html|accessdate=6 Feb 2009|work=[[The Japan Times]]|title=Young at heart, but never free of Johnny|date=15 Sep 1999|author=Phillip Brasor}} Kitagawa's focus is on the development of his group as complete entertainers. Shonentai, for example, did not release a single until it had been together for more than seven years. "I'm not very interested in records," Kitagawa said in a 1996 interview. "Once you release a record, you have to sell that record. You have to push one song only. You can't think of anything else. It's not good for the artist." {{cite journal |last1=McClure |first1=Steve |year=1996 |title=You Look Like a Music Star |journal=Billboard |volume=108 |issue=35 |pages=76–80 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vwcEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA76&dq=johnny+kitagawa&cd=2#v=onepage&q=johnny+kitagawa&f=false |issn=0006-2510 |publisher=Nielsen Business Media|accessdate = January 30, 2010}} Once launched, Kitagawa has been known to use his established groups to induce television stations to report on his newer acts, and ensure favorable press coverage for his acts and himself.{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CE6D9113EF937A25757C0A9669C8B63|accessdate=4 Feb 2009|date=14 Apr 2000|title=Lawmakers In Japan Hear Grim Sex Case|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Calvin Sims}} Programs that give unfavorable coverage do not receive interviews or television appearance from popular stars managed by Kitagawa. Kitagawa maintains a high degree of control over his acts,{{cite web|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fd20070916pb.html|accessdate=2 Feb 2009|author=Phillip Brasor|work= [[The Japan Times]]|date=16 Sep 2007|title=They're fey, maybe not gay, but anyway, the 'talent' are coming out to play}} to the extent that their images do not appear on the company website. Performers are expected to maintain a public image that is conducive to marketing to young women; as a result, members of bands produced by Kitagawa avoid public mention of their private lives. Kitagawa himself avoids the public spotlight as well. He rarely permits his photograph to be taken, and does not make public appearances with his groups. ==Sexual harassment claims and libel suit== Rumors concerning Kitagawa and possible [[sexual harassment]] of the youth in his employ had surrounded the agency since 1988, when {{nihongo|Koji Kita|北公次|''Kita Kōji''}}, a former member of Four Leaves, published a series of diaries under the title {{nihongo|''Hikaru Genji e''|光Genjiへ|To [[Hikaru Genji (band)|Hikaru Genji]]}}. Kita claimed that Kitagawa had used his position of influence over the group to make unwanted sexual advances towards the boys under contract to him.{{nihongo|Koji Kita|北公次|''Kita Kōji''}}, {{nihongo|''Hikaru Genji e''|光Genjiへ|}}, Publisher: {{nihongo|Data House|データハウス|''dēta hausu''}}, December 1988 Similar allegations were made in a book published in 1996 by Junya Hiramoto, a former member of another of Kitagawa's bands. Hiramoto alleged that he had seen Kitagawa force a boy to have sex with him in one of the talent agency's dormitories.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/Archive/Article/0,4273,4011093,00.html|accessdate=4 Feb 2009|work=Kobe Observer|title=Japan's star-maker accused of sexually abusing boys|date=23 April 2000|author=Justin McCurry | location=London}} Later, in 1999, the weekly magazine {{nihongo|''[[Shukan Bunshun]]''|週刊文春|}} printed a ten-part series that detailed numerous allegations of sexual improprieties. The accusers were a dozen teenage boys who had been recruited into the Johnny & Associates organization, who spoke on condition of anonymity. In addition, the series also accused Kitagawa of permitting minors in his employ to drink alcohol and smoke. The accusations prompted international newspaper coverage.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/library/world/asia/013000japan-talent.html|title=In Japan, Tarnishing a Star Maker|accessdate=2 Feb 2009|work=[[The New York Times]]|date = 30 Jan 2000}} The controversy resulted in Yoshihide Sakaue, a member of the [[Diet of Japan|Parliament]], holding a hearing on the matter in April, 2000. Sakaue said that as a result of the media coverage, and in response to a request from a constituent, he wanted to examine whether government officials had properly investigated complaints about Kitagawa. Officials of the National Police Agency acknowledged that they had investigated Kitagawa's agency, but had not determined that sexual harassment had occurred. Officials did indicate that Kitagawa's company was warned about permitting minors to use alcohol and smoke cigarettes. The National Police and Welfare Ministry indicated that under the Ministry's understanding of the law, even if the allegations against Kitagawa were true, the acts could not be considered [[child abuse]] because Kitagawa was neither parent nor guardian to the boys in his employ. In addition, officials testified that neither the boys nor their parents had pursued a criminal complaint against Kitagawa. Kitagawa denied any wrongdoing, and his attorney characterized the claims as being from disgruntled former employees voicing discontent. Kitagawa sued ''Shukan Bunshun'' for [[defamation|libel]]. Other than ''Shukan Bunshun'', none of the major Japanese media covered the story of the allegations against Kitagawa, the hearing in Parliament, or the Kitagawa lawsuit. ''[[The New York Times]]'' attributed this lack of coverage to Kitagawa's influence over the popular [[News media|media]]. Once ''Shukan Bunshun'' began publication of the series, [[Johnny & Associates]] denied the magazine, and the other media owned by its parent organization, access to any of its performers. After protracted litigation, in 2002 the [[Tokyo District Court]] awarded Kitagawa an 8.8 million yen judgment against ''Shukan Bunshun'', finding that the articles defamed him. ''[[Shukan Bunshun]]'' appealed the ruling. In a partial reversal of the district court, the [[Tokyo High Court]] in 2003 ruled that the ''Shukan Bunshun'' series did in fact defame Kitagawa; however, it ruled that the defamatory content of the articles was limited to the allegations that Kitagawa had provided minors with alcohol and tobacco products. The court found that the ''Shukan Bunshun'' had sufficient reason to accept as trustworthy, and publish, the sexual allegations by Kitagawa's former clients. Kitagawa appealed this decision to the [[Supreme Court of Japan|Supreme Court]], but in 2004 it rejected his appeal.{{cite book|title=Secrets, Sex, and Spectacle: The Rules of Scandal in Japan and the United States|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A9CDvNs35ooC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Secrets,+Sex,+and+Spectacle:+The+Rules+of+Scandal+in+Japan+and+the+United+States|ISBN=0-226-89408-8|author=Mark D. West|publisher=University of Chicago Press|page=210}} ==Post-litigation activities== In 2006, the boy band [[KAT-TUN]] was promoted to major band status and has all their 20 singles, DVD releases and 6 studio albums to date reach #1 on the prestigious [[Oricon]] music charts; the Japanese equivalent of the American [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] music charts. In 2007, temporary [[Johnny's Jr]]. group, [[Hey! Say! JUMP|Hey! Say! 7]], broke a record as the youngest male group to ever top Oricon charts, with an average age of 14.8 years.{{cite web|url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/news/rankmusic/47004/|accessdate = 23 Mar 2009|work = [[Oricon Style]]|title = Hey! Say! 7 youngest boy band's place in history (Japanese)}} Later that year, [[Hey! Say! JUMP]] broke a record as the largest group to debut in [[Johnny's Entertainment|Johnny's]] history, with ten members. Kitagawa, as of September, 2007, continued to be involved in the regular operation of [[Johnny & Associates]]. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kitagawa, Johnny}} [[Category:Talent managers]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:Japanese businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Los Angeles]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1931 births]] [[Category:American people of Japanese descent]]
